statement: If the only way to save another person's life during an emergency is to sacrifice one's own leg, then one is morally permitted to prioritize preserving one's own leg.
It is morally right to allow several innocent people to suffer harm rather than harm a single innocent person as a means of helping several.
From a moral point of view, we should not feel obliged to give one of our kidneys to a person with kidney failure, even though we don't need two kidneys to survive, but really only one to be healthy.
Political oppression should not be used, even if opression for a short, limited time would ensure the overall well-being and happiness of the people.

From a moral perspective, people should prioritize the well-being of those who are especially close to them either physically or emotionally; they should not care about the well-being of all human beings on the planet equally.
It is permissible to allow hundreds of people to die from a bomb if prevention necesitates torturing an innocent person to provide information.
It is far less wrong to fail to help someone than it is to actively harm them yourself.
Sometimes it is morally necessary to spare innocent people as collateral damageâ€”even if fewer people are saved overall.
It is morally permissible to keep money that one doesn't really need even if one can donate it to causes that provide effective help to those who will benefit a great deal.
